Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Story:
I glanced at my phone, the group chat buzzing with messages from my family. “Don’t forget, we’re all meeting at Grandma’s at noon!” my older brother reminded me. It was our annual holiday lunch, and everyone expected me to be there, laughing and sharing stories, just like every year. But as I set down my phone, my client, Mrs. Lee, smiled at me in the salon chair. “Could you just trim my fringe a little more? I know you’re busy, but I’d really appreciate it.” She was one of my regulars, always kind, and I knew how much she trusted me to get her hair just right.

I felt the pressure building inside me. My family wanted me present, fully engaged in our tradition, not distracted or late. But Mrs. Lee deserved my full attention too; she relied on me to make her feel confident and heard. I could already imagine my mom’s disappointed look if I showed up late, and Mrs. Lee’s gentle smile fading if I rushed her. Torn between being the dependable sister and the attentive hairdresser, I stood there, scissors in hand, heart pounding, unsure which role to honor first.
